Award.AwardTitle: Support for the International Conference on Science and Technology of Synthetic Metals 2012
Award.AbstractNarration: This grant provides partial support for the International Conference on Science and Technology of Synthetic Metals in Atlanta, Georgia, in July 2012. The conference is on the physics, chemistry, materials science and engineering, and technological applications of polymers and conducting organic molecular crystals. It is designed to provide the US organic semiconductors community with an international forum to discuss the state-of-the-art regarding not only the fundamental aspects, but also, significantly, the technology drivers. In addition, by holding the conference in the Southeast region of the US and with the support of the Georgia Institute of Technology, there will be a remarkable opportunity to broaden participation in the topical areas, through a concerted effort to attract both women and under-represented minorities to the Conference. All NSF funding will be used to support the registration of women and under-represented minority researchers or faculty members who are professors at a minority serving institution and who will bring minority students with them to the conference.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Close to 800 participants from 40 countries across the world gathered at the Hyatt Regency Downtown in Atlanta, GA for the International Conference on Science and Technology of Synthetic Metals (ICSM 2012), July 8 – 13, 2012.   The conference was organized by Professors Jean-Luc Bredas and Seth R. Marder, aided by the local organizing committee of Professors Ana Arias (University of California at Berkeley), Ray Baughman (University of Texas at Dallas), James Brooks (Florida State University), Arthur Epstein (Ohio State University), Daniel Frisbie (University of Minnesota), Antoine Kahn (Princeton University), Bernard Kippelen (Georgia Institute of Technology), Lynn Loo (Princeton University), Sumit Mazumdar (University of Arizona), Robert Metzger (University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa), Thuc-Quyen Nguyen (University of California at Santa Barbara), Elsa Reichmanis (Georgia Institute of Technology), John Reynolds (Georgia Institute of Technology), Mark Thompson (University of Southern California) and Z. Valy Vardeny (University of Utah).

 

After a welcoming reception on Sunday evening at the Hyatt, the Conference truly started on Monday morning with two plenary lectures kicking-off five days of oral presentations, discussions, and poster sessions. This international forum provided a diverse set of researchers with an opportunity to discuss their new research and results in the context of conductor, superconductor, and semiconductor organic materials, their synthesis, characterization, and application in devices such as organic field-effect transistors, light-emitting diodes, or solar cells.

 

The Conference (which featured 10 plenary lectures, 96 invited talks, 136 short talks, and over 300 posters), created a vehicle for broad dissemination of results in the area of conducting and semiconducting organic materials. In addition editors from the American Chemical Society, Royal Society of Chemistry and Journal of Polymer Science attended, which increased the visibility of the field and its researchers. The inherent multi-disciplinary nature of the field of conducting and semiconducting organic materials and the diverse set of participants at the meeting led to significant cross fertilization of ideas.

The Co-Chairs paid special attention to ensure adequate representation of women and under-represented minorities. At least 20 to 25% of the members of the Local Organizing Committee and International Advisory Board, of the plenary speakers, of the invited speakers, and of the session chairs were women or under-represented minorities.

The International Advisory Board unanimously adopted guidelines for participation to the International Advisory Board, which will ensure that it maintains a diverse representation in the future. The ICSM-2014 Conference will be held in Turku, Finland. It was decided in Atlanta that the 2016 edition will take place in Guanzhou, PR China.
